unnormalised: Okay, here's the generated Quora post based on the input parameters, focused on e-commerce transactions with unnormalized number formats:
normalised: So, you're asking about the kind of numbers you see when you're buying stuff online, right? Well, it's a mix of everything! You've got the price, of course – things like rupee four hundred and ninety nine, rupee nine hundred and ninety nine, or even just seven hundred and fifty I-N-R. Then there are discounts, maybe "twenty percent off" or "Save rupee one hundred". Shipping charges might be "rupee fifty" or "Free on orders above rupee seven hundred and ninety nine." Keep an eye out for those!

unnormalised: So, you're asking about the kind of numbers you see when you're buying stuff online, right? Well, it's a mix of everything! You've got the price, of course – things like Rs. 499, ₹ 999.00, or even just 750 INR. Then there are discounts, maybe "20% off" or "Save ₹100". Shipping charges might be "Rs 50" or "Free on orders above Rs 799." Keep an eye out for those!
normalised: Beyond the actual cost, you'll see order numbers like "Order I-D: hash one two three four five six seven eight nine zero", or tracking numbers that look like "A-W-B: one Z two three four A-B-C five six seven D-E-F eight nine zero". Estimated delivery dates also pop up: "Delivered by twenty fifth december two thousand and twenty four" or "Expected arrival: December twenty fifth." Payment confirmation messages use numbers too, like "Transaction successful: rupee six hundred and fifty debited from your account." Don't forget ratings: "four point five divided by five stars".

unnormalised: Beyond the actual cost, you'll see order numbers like "Order ID: #1234567890", or tracking numbers that look like "AWB: 1Z234ABC567DEF890". Estimated delivery dates also pop up: "Delivered by 25/12/2024" or "Expected arrival: Dec 25th." Payment confirmation messages use numbers too, like "Transaction successful: ₹650 debited from your account." Don't forget ratings: "4.5/5 stars".
normalised: Finally, remember quantities – "Quantity: two" or "Add one to cart". Size charts often use centimeters or inches to give measurements. Keep a close look at everything, double-check those costs before confirming, and happy shopping!

unnormalised: Finally, remember quantities – "Qty: 2" or "Add 1 to cart". Size charts often use centimeters (cm) or inches (in) to give measurements. Keep a close look at everything, double-check those costs before confirming, and happy shopping!
